Message.Issue: Implement IDisposable on 'Camera' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'PS3Camera'. If 'Camera' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

Implement IDisposable on 'DirectShowCamera' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'DsROTEntry', 'Image<Bgr, byte>'. If 'DirectShowCamera' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.
Implement IDisposable on 'DirectShowCamera'.

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor() CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor() CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean DirectShowCamera.NewCamera(DsDevice, Int32, Int32, Int32):Void CameraBase.Cleanup():Void

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera(DsDevice, int)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor(DsDevice, Int32) CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera(DsDevice, int)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor(DsDevice, Int32) CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean DirectShowCamera.NewCamera(DsDevice, Int32, Int32, Int32):Void CameraBase.Cleanup():Void

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera(DsDevice, int, int)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor(DsDevice, Int32, Int32) CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera(DsDevice, int, int)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor(DsDevice, Int32, Int32) CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean DirectShowCamera.NewCamera(DsDevice, Int32, Int32, Int32):Void CameraBase.Cleanup():Void

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera(DsDevice, int, int, int, int, int)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor(DsDevice, Int32, Int32, Int32, Int32, Int32) CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean

'DirectShowCamera.DirectShowCamera(DsDevice, int, int, int, int, int)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
DirectShowCamera..ctor(DsDevice, Int32, Int32, Int32, Int32, Int32) CameraBase.Initialize():Boolean DirectShowCamera.NewCamera(DsDevice, Int32, Int32, Int32):Void CameraBase.Cleanup():Void
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'DirectShowCamera.CloseHandle(IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'DirectShowCamera.CopyMemory(IntPtr, IntPtr, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'DirectShowCamera.CreateFileMapping(IntPtr, IntPtr, uint, uint, uint, string)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'name' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'DirectShowCamera.MapViewOfFile(IntPtr, uint, uint, uint, uint)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

As it is declared in your code, parameter 'numberOfBytesToMap' of P/Invoke 'DirectShowCamera.MapViewOfFile(IntPtr, uint, uint, uint, uint)' will be 4 bytes wide on 64-bit platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be 8 bytes wide on 64-bit platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of 'uint'.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'DirectShowCamera.UnmapViewOfFile(IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Declare the first parameter of 'DirectShowCamera.FrameCapHandler' as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of 'DirectShowCamera.FrameCapHandler' as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Implement IDisposable on 'DirectShowDevices'.

Implement IDisposable on 'FileStreamCamera' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'Image<Gray, byte>'. If 'FileStreamCamera' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

'FileStreamCamera.FileStreamCamera(string, bool)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
FileStreamCamera..ctor(String, Boolean) CameraBase.ClearROI():Void

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'lpName' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. Rule.Name: Declare event handlers correctly
Rule.Description: By convention, .NET events have two parameters that specify the event sender and event data. Event handler signatures should follow this form: void MyEventHandler(object sender, EventArgs e). The 'sender' parameter is always of type System.Object, even if it is possible to employ a more specific type. The 'e' parameter is always of type System.EventArgs. Events that do not provide event data should use the System.EventHandler delegate type. Event handlers return void so that they can send each event to multiple target methods. Any value returned by a target would be lost after the first call.
Rule.Resolution: Declare the first parameter of {0} as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of {0} as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.

Rule.Name: Do not call overridable methods in constructors
Rule.Description: Virtual methods defined on the class should not be called from constructors. If a derived class has overridden the method, the derived class version will be called (before the derived class constructor is called).
Rule.Resolution: {0} contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences: {1}

Rule.Name: Implement IDisposable correctly
Rule.Description: All IDisposable types should implement the Dispose pattern correctly.
Rule.Resolution: Ensure that {0} is declared as protected, virtual, and unsealed.

Rule.Name: Move P/Invokes to NativeMethods class
Rule.Description: This type contains members with the DllImport attribute. Members with the DllImport attribute should be contained in classes named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Rule.Resolution: Because it is a P/Invoke method, {0} should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Rule.Name: P/Invoke declarations should be portable
Rule.Resolution: As it is declared in your code, parameter {0} of P/Invoke {1} will be {2} bytes wide on {3} platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be {4} bytes wide on {3} platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of {5}.

As it is declared in your code, the return type of P/Invoke {0} will be {1} bytes wide on {2} platforms. This is not correct, as the actual native declaration of this API indicates it should be {3} bytes wide on {2} platforms. Consult the MSDN Platform SDK documentation for help determining what data type should be used instead of {4}.

Rule.Name: P/Invoke entry points should exist
Rule.Description: Methods decorated with the DllImport attribute should point to existing unmanaged entry points. There is no compile-time check to ensure that methods decorated with the DllImport attribute actually exist in the referenced unmanaged dll. In the event that an entry point does not exist or the specified argument list is not correct, a runtime exception will be generated.
Rule.Resolution: Correct the declaration of {0} so that it correctly points to an existing entry point in {1}. The unmanaged entry point name currently linked to is {2}.

Rule.Name: P/Invokes should not be visible
Rule.Description: Interop layer should not be public. The DllImport attribute should not be applied to publicly accessible members (public or protected).
Rule.Resolution: Change the accessibility of P/Invoke {0} so that it is no longer visible from outside its assembly.

Rule.Name: Specify marshaling for P/Invoke string arguments
Rule.Description: When marshaling strings as ANSI (or as Auto on Win9x), some characters may be changed. If best-fit mapping is on, strings that appear different in Unicode will be marshaled to identical ANSI strings, which may lead to incorrect security decisions. Turning best-fit mapping off reduces this risk, as all characters without equivalents are mapped to '?'. Also, note that CharSet.Ansi is the default setting for all string marshaling; Unicode marshaling must be specified explicitly, either as a CharSet setting of DllImport or StructLayout, or as a MarshalAs attribute with a Unicode (or system-dependent) UnmanagedType.
Rule.Resolution: To reduce security risk, marshal parameter {0} as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.

Rule.Name: Types that own disposable fields should be disposable
Rule.Description: Types that declare disposable members should also implement IDisposable. If the type does not own any unmanaged resources, do not implement a finalizer on it.
Rule.Resolution: Implement IDisposable on {0} because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: {1}. If {0} has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

Rule.Name: Types that own native resources should be disposable
Rule.Description: Types that allocate unmanaged resources should implement IDisposable to allow callers to release those resources on demand. Failure to implement IDisposable can result in unmanaged resources being unavailable or underutilized.
